Polytechnique, Montreal, QC H3T 1J4, Canada c DST Thematic Unit of Excellence on Soft Nanofabrication, Centre for Environmental Science & Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur, UP 208016, India DST Thematic Unit of Excellence on Soft Nanofabrication Centre for Environmental Science & Engineering Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur Kanpur UP 208016 India cDST Thematic Unit of Excellence on Soft Nanofabrication, Centre for Environmental Science & Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur, UP 208016, India d School of Engineering and applied sciences, Allahabad University, Navrangpura, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380009, India School of Engineering and applied sciences Allahabad University, Navrangpura Ahmedabad Gujarat 380009 India dSchool of Engineering and applied sciences, Allahabad University, Navrangpura, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380009, India ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Authors contributed equally for the work Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is a catalytic process, which is used in petroleum refineries to reach sulfur levels <5 ppm of energy fuels due to its higher rate and activity for desulfurization. HDS reaction performance is mainly controlled by the sulfided phase of catalysts e.g., NiMoS/CoMoS sites for NiMo/CoMo based catalysts, and the formation of these sites depends on the catalyst design properties such as active metal dispersion, metal-support interaction, physiochemical properties like surface area/porosity and structure/morphology of catalysts based on their preparation methods/sulfidation conditions. In addition, operating conditions of reaction also govern the performance of the HDS process. A significant number of theoretical as well as experimental studies is available in literature, exploring various catalysts/technologies for HDS reaction. This review paper summarizes all these available strategies in detail and specially focuses on the effect of all mentioned parameters on HDS catalyst activity. Further, this work also discusses the required design charactertics for an ideal HDS catalyst. The prime concern of this review study is focused on highlighting and filling the gap between experimental and theoretical explanations for HDS catalysts, which is very important to analyze the HDS process performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In a rising oil demand situation, the main objective of petroleum refineries is to produce a high yield of valuable products (e.g., gasoline, diesel, jet fuels etc.) from the crude oil feed of variable composition [1,2]. Crude oil contains hydrocarbons and different compounds containing heteroatoms (e.g. sulfur (S), nitrogen (N) and oxygen (O)), which can cause many health and environmental problems such as the presence of sulfur compounds may create major respiratory issues if inhaled [3,4]. Furthermore, sulfur deactivates noble metal-based catalysts in reforming units and corrodes refinery equipment. Therefore, strict environmental regulations have been placed worldwide to reduce sulfur content to < 5 ppm [5–9]. Burning of sulfur-containing compounds (e.g., mono/di sulfides, thiophenes, dibenzothiophene (DBT), 4-methyl dibenzothiophene (4-MDBT), 4,6-dimethyl dibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT), and benzonaphthothiophene (BNT)) in an internal combustion engine result in formation of SOx emissions which is one of the significant constituents of acid rain. It is worth to note here that lighter sulfur compounds (sulfides and thiophenes) are found in lighter fuels (e.g., gasoline) while bigger molecules (DBT, DMDBT) are found in heavy energy fuels (e.g., diesel). Therefore, all the process parameters and choice of catalysts, are totally based on the feed properties [1,2]. In this regard, a huge amount of effort has been invested by research laboratories and refineries to develop feasible methods such as hydrodesulfurization (HDS), oxidative desulfurization (ODS) [4,5,9], adsorptive removal (ADS) [6], pervaporation [7] and other desulfurization (BDS) [2–4,8] to reduce the sulfur content present in transportation fuels. Among all the technologies mentioned above (mainly used at lab scale level), HDS is widely used by refineries worldwide to remove heavy sulfur compounds. It is a catalytic chemical process, in which oil-based raw material and hydrogen gas is passed over a catalyst bed at an elevated temperature of around 300–400℃ and 30–130 atm. reactor pressure. The sulfur atom of molecule is adsorbed on the sulfur vacancies (which are considered to be the active sites) of HDS catalysts and desulfurized product emerges out along with hydrogen sulphide (H2S) as a byproduct [9]. A simple HDS reaction can be described by following equation. R-SH + H2→R-H + H2S Although HDS is the most explored commercial process used in all petroleum refineries, there is an urgent need for development/ improvements in the design of the catalyst to meet the current requirement. It is worth mentioning here that HDS is a costly process due to high precision of safety requirements, high operating and instrument conditions (due to very high temperature (300–400℃) and pressure (10–130 bar)) and high hydrogen consumption, which again can be addressed by upgrading the design of catalyst [10,14]. Various catalysts have been explored, and among all, Ni/Co-promoted molybdenum or tungsten sulfide (MoS2/WS2) catalysts supported on different materials (ℽ-Al2O3/SiO2/ TiO2/ Monoliths) using conventional wet-impregnation method are the most widely used catalysts in refineries [1,10,11]. As the adsorption of reactant sulfur molecule mainly depends on the sulfur vacancy of the catalyst, the calcined oxide catalyst (Ni/Co-promoted MoO3/WO3) is first converted to sulfide phase, and then sulfur vacancies are created at its surface in the presence of H2 [12]. After sulfidation, MoS2/WS2 is a hexagonal layered structure and it is prepared as a stack of these layers in the catalysts along with the Ni/Co promoters at the edges of these layers [13]. These prepared NiMoS/CoMoS (Ni/Co edge decorated MoS2/WS2 layers) phases are the active sites for HDS reaction. However, various problems are faced in the formation of these HDS active sites (Fig. 1 ), such as strong-metal support interactions (i.e., formation of Mo-O-Al bond and inactive spinels, i.e., NiAl2O4/CoAl2O4 [14,15]) leading to the formation of incomplete sulfidation or type 1 sites (single layer partially sulfided NiMoS/CoMoS sites) which ultimately limit the formation of highly active NiMoS/CoMoS type 2 sites (multilayer completely sulfided sites) [1,10] and the segregation of inactive NixSy/CoxSy phases [27–29] (itself inactive site for HDS reaction and also block the active NiMoS/CoMoS sites) may also form on the catalyst surface because their formation is thermodynamically favorable in the given HDS conditions. In addition, these catalysts also suffer from problems of control over the particle size and monodispersity, which are directly related to HDS activity [6]. Therefore, complete sulfur removal for HDS reaction using the available conventional catalysts has still not been accomplished. But, based on the above explanations, an ideal catalyst model for HDS reaction may be proposed as follows: it should have the maximum formation of active NiMoS/CoMoS sites, which may be possible through easier reducibility or suitability (type-II sites), negligible inactive sites segregation, low particle size (< 2 nm), high dispersion of active metal on the surface of support and enhanced Mo edge atoms (according to Rim-edge model) with desired stacking degree. Nitrogen-containing compounds significantly influence fuel quality by impacting both stability and engine performance. Even in trace amounts, these compounds can compromise fuel stability during storage by promoting gum formation and can also deactivate key refining catalysts—particularly those involved in sulfur and aromatic removal in diesel streams [14]. These nitrogen species are more readily denitrogenated on direct desulfurization (DDS) catalyst sites than on hydrogenation (HYD) sites. As a result, the presence of nitrogen compounds tends to strongly inhibit the HYD pathway of hydrodesulfurization (HDS), while the DDS pathway remains comparatively less affected. Typical nitrogen compounds found in petroleum are heterocyclic structures, often composed of one or more five- or six-membered rings. Among these, basic nitrogen compounds like quinoline and non-basic ones like indole have been identified as primary inhibitors of HDS. A 2017 study by Tao et al. [15] investigated the inhibitory effects of quinoline and indole on NiW/Al2O3 catalysts. The findings showed that while quinoline is more readily converted, it is more resistant to denitrogenation than indole. Moreover, quinoline exhibited a stronger inhibitory effect on the desulfurization of individual sulfur compounds in gas oil compared to indole. To prevent nitrogen compounds from adsorbing on HDS catalyst sites, it can be either remove before the reaction or modify the catalyst. Removing nitrogen compounds is the most effective method, and it can be done through processes like adsorption, extraction, or denitrogenation. Alternatively, it can be tried to make the catalyst less susceptible to nitrogen compound adsorption by modifying its surface chemistry or adding specific inhibitors. Many refineries and laboratories have been continuously working to develop this ideal catalyst e.g., in 2004, Exxon Mobil Company developed “Nebula Catalyst Technology”, considered the best hydroprocessing catalyst with breakthrough activity [7]. Further, Honeywell UOP Company manufactured ULTIMet catalyst, which is significantly more active than traditional HDS catalysts. In recent years, some new approaches also introduced to address desulfurization process such as ammonia/amine intercalated MoS2 catalysts [15], water/deuterium donor capacity in desulfurization [16], machine learning approach [17] and effect of predenitrogenation [18]. Though the catalysts mentioned above are available in the market and improvements have been observed in last 20 years, it has not yet reached the cost milestone. It is worth mentioning here that several review papers are available in the literature based on various aspects of hydrodesulfurization and different parameters affecting HDS catalytic activity and selectivity. Besenbacher et al., [10] reviewed combined experimental (Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM), High-angle Annular Dark-field (HAADF)-STM) and computational (DFT) tools to understand the structure, mechanism, and size effect of both promoted and unpromoted MoS2 catalyst, whereas Hinnemann et al., [11] reviewed structure and mechanistic pathway of hydrodesulfurization catalysts by DFT. Recently, Pham and zwain et at, [13,14] reviewed the advances of HDS catalysts like the role of promoters, supports, active phases and synthesis strategies for better HDS activity, but still, some lacunae exist in the literature, and there is a need for detailed, comprehensive study for theoretical and experimental reports available on HDS and develop a relation like how these two approaches support each other’s observations. The present review is focused on the technologies explored in the field of catalyst design and how these modifications (various promoters, supports, active phases, additives, preparation methods, sulfidation conditions etc.) affect the HDS activity (theoretically and experimentally), deep study of various catalyst structures and their HDS reaction mechanisms to explain that how catalyst structures contribute for better HDS performance through DFT method, and also the optimized reaction conditions required for hydrodesulfurization reaction etc. Thus, the prime concern of this review study is focused on highlighting and filling the gap between experimental and theoretical explanations for HDS catalysts. Studying both approaches is essential to see an accurate picture of the HDS process and catalyst. 1.1 Reaction mechanism Crude oil contains various sulphur-containing compounds such as thiophenes, dibenzyl thiophenes, dimethyl dibenzothiophene (Table 1 ) etc., which can have different reactivities (as mentioned earlier, heavy or bulky sulfur compounds are difficult to remove due to steric hindrance of extra benzene ring or methyl groups like DBT, DMDBT and TMDBT) and thus, it is essential to understand the reaction mechanism for the design of efficient catalyst [12]. The HDS reaction mechanism was first proposed by N∅rskov and his coworkers, and this has been later supported by various DFT studies by the adsorption of different molecules on different catalyst surfaces. The desulphurization reaction mechanism (Fig. 2 ) generally follows four steps: i) Formation of S-vacancy when H2 interact with the sulfided catalyst and releases H2S gas, ii) Adsorption/interaction of sulfur compound over the unsaturated metal atom (formation of M-S bond) iii) Hydrogenolysis of C-S bond and, removal of the desulphurized compound, iv) regeneration of the catalyst [19]. It is important to note that the main reaction (i.e., bond breaking) happens in step 3, which can follow two reaction pathways: i) direct desulfurization (DDS) and ii) hydrogenation (HYD) pathways. Fig. 3 demonstrates the conversion of dibenzothiophene (DBT) to cyclohexylbenzene (CHB)/bicyclohexyl (BCH) in which biphenyl (BP) is formed as intermediate in DDS pathway, whereas tetrahydrodibenzotiophene (THDBT) in HYD pathway. Many reports suggest that biphenyl (BP) is the dominant product in DDS pathway, whereas cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) dominants in HYD pathway [19]. It is worth noting that hydrogen consumption is higher in the case of the HYD pathway than the DDS route. 1.2 Heuristics to design the HDS catalysts According to the reaction mechanism in Fig. 2, the following approaches may be adapted to prepare an ideal catalyst for the HDS reaction. 1.2.1 Sulfur vacancy The HDS process removes sulfur from petroleum fractions in the presence of a suitable catalyst. So, the first requirement is to create a sulfur vacancy on the surface of the catalyst, and the creation of sulfur vacancy (step 1 in Fig. 2) is mainly based on metal sulfur bond strength (M-S) in the catalyst. As per the Sabatier principle of catalysis, metal-sulfur bond energy should be optimum for an ideal HDS catalyst [20]. If the M-S bond is too strong, it is hard to break it, so creating sulfur vacancy will be difficult. Further, if the M-S bond is too weak, reaction will not happen as the M-S bond will break again instead of the C-S bond during the reaction [21]. 1.2.2 Adsorption of reactants over a sulfur vacancy In the second step of the reaction mechanism, a sulfur-containing compound should adsorb on the sulfur vacancy created on the surface of the catalyst. Adsorption of reactant compound is highly dependent on the nature of the catalyst and the feed compound. Petroleum feed may contain lighter sulfur compound like dimethyl sulfide, thiophene, DBT etc. as well as heavier sulfur compounds like 4,6 DMDBT, 3,5 DMDBT etc. [22]. Depending on the feed sulfur compound, two kinds of adsorption may happen in the HDS reaction: (1) head-on adsorption (2) planar adsorption (Fig. 4 ). Generally, lighter compounds favour DDS pathways and head-on adsorption in which the S atom of the compound directly comes in contact with the catalyst. However, bulky compounds favour HYD pathways and planar adsorption in which the S atom cannot come in direct contact with the catalyst due to steric hindrance, so aromatic ring hydrogenation happens before desulfurization. 1.2.3 Nature of the HDS catalyst 1.2.3.1 Morphology According to the well-known rim-edge model (Fig. 5 ), the HDS catalyst can be explained as a stack of circular discs in which one disc corresponds to one layer of metal sulfide catalyst like MoS2/WS2. Based on this model, Chianelli claimed [24] that two kinds of sites are available on HDS catalysts: rim sites and edge sites (top and bottom layers have rim sites at the edges, the top surface away from the edges called basal inert plane and layers sandwiched in the middle have only edge sites) in which rim sites favour the HYD and DDS both pathways but edge sites favor only DDS pathways [25]. According to this model, as the number of stacking layers increases, rim site density decreases, and as the slab length of a layer decreases, edge site density increases. Therefore, for complete desulfurization of petroleum feed, an ideal catalyst should have an optimum stacking degree and smaller slab length for greater rim sites and higher edge site fractions, respectively. 1.2.3.2 Particle size and surface area Catalytic active sites directly depend on the available catalyst surface area, and the smaller the particle size, the more the surface area of the catalyst would be. Further, the higher surface area also results in good active site dispersion, which mainly governs the reaction performance because metal dispersion is the percentage of metal available on the catalyst surface for reaction divided by the total metal content of the catalyst [22–24]. Therefore, an ideal HDS catalyst should have a higher surface area or metal dispersion but a smaller particle size. 1.2.3.3 Metal-support interactions Further, metal-support interaction is the bond formation between a metal or metal oxide and the support of a catalyst, such as a Mo-O-Al bond for a Mo/Al2O3 catalyst. The strength of this bond decides the degree of metal support interaction, which further affects the metal dispersion and sulfidation process of the HDS catalyst [NiMo, CoMo]. The stronger the metal support interaction, the lesser the catalyst's reducibility, which ultimately means lesser sulfidation. In HDS literature, two kinds of sites are introduced: type 1 and type 2 sites in which type 1 sites correspond to strong metal support interaction and type 2 sites correspond to weak metal support interaction. For an ideal HDS catalyst, the sulfidation degree should be at its maximum to have more and more sulfur vacancy on the catalyst [20–25]. Therefore, weak metal support interaction or higher type 2 sites are desired for better HDS performance. 1.2.3.4 Acid sites The activity and selectivity of the catalyst are also greatly influenced by the acidic properties of the supports. Basically, two types of acid sites are present over the catalyst surface, i.e., Bronsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites. Bronsted sites donate protons (H +), and Lewis sites accept electron pairs [26,27]. Lewis sites of the support govern the metal-support interaction, so optimum Lewis sites are desired for an ideal HDS catalyst. Bronsted sites make the formation of sulfur vacancy (coordinatively unsaturated site, CUS) easier by effecting the electronic behaviour of the catalyst (as shown in Fig. 6 ) and enhancing the acidity of the SH sites. This dual effect promotes the enhancement of HDS activities and the HYD activity of the catalyst. The support Bronsted acidity also enhances the intrinsic activities of the potential active sites for HDS reactions. Apart from that, the existence of Bronsted acid sites also induces isomerization activity over the catalyst surface, which further helps improve the HDS performance of the resulting catalyst [28]. 2 HDS catalysts In refineries, the untreated feed is generally extremely inhomogeneous, which puts enormous demands on the performance and flexibility of the catalyst to ensure a homogeneous output. Various catalyst combinations are explored for HDS reaction, but the final catalyst selection is based on the nature of the feed as well as the specifications of the corresponding products. Molybdenum (Mo) and Tungsten (W) sulfides are the active catalysts for HDS reaction. However, it is worth understanding the bare catalyst first. Bulk MS2 (M = Mo and W) is a semiconductor with the indirect band gap of 1.2 eV (MoS2) and 1.32 eV (WS2), it consists of S-Mo-S layered hexagonal sheets which are connected by Vander Waals forces just like graphite. Fig. 7 A clearly shows that in each sheet, the Mo atom layer is sandwiched between the S atom layer [29]. Fig. 7B exposes principally two types of low-index edges of the MS2 slab: the metal terminated edge ((1010¯) Mo-edge) and the sulfur terminated edge ((1010 ¯) S-edge). It has been observed that the S-edge is more active and favorable for the promoted phase. It is known that the basal plane of the catalyst is inert, and only the edges of the catalyst surface exhibit catalytic active sites [29]. A series of these monometallic (MoS2/WS2), along with other metals forming bimetallic/trimetallic and also some multimetallic catalysts, have been explored for HDS reaction, which is discussed in the following sections here: 2.1 Monometallic and bimetallic catalysts In earlier centuries, the research work of the HDS process started with monometallic catalysts, which contain one active metal (most frequently Mo or W metal) and sulfides of this active metal (MoS2 or WS2) considered to be the active phase for these catalysts. Afterwards, different experimental and theoretical studies on HDS proved that adding Co or Ni (as a promoter) to these monometallic catalysts resulted in a massive increase in catalytic activity. This Ni/Co-promoted MoS2 or WS2 catalyst is called a bimetallic catalyst. Further, different computational studies reveal that Co and Ni work as promoters located at the edges of the MoS2 layer, and this Mo edge site substitution by Ni/Co enhances the vacancy formation as well as generates new highly active sites [10] which increases the activity of catalyst more than an order of magnitude. The promotion action is through the formation of the Co-Mo-S [30], Ni-Mo-S [31,32] and the Ni-W-S phase [33], which act as the HDS active phases for these bimetallic catalysts. Theoretical methods (DFT) were employed to find the electronic explanations for this promotion effect for different 3d and 4d transition metals like Ni or Co. In these DFT studies, different volcanic curves were plotted relating an optimum value of a parameter generally called descriptor (metal-sulfur bond strength) with the HDS catalytic activity for the given set of bimetallic catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 , the trends obtained correlated well with the Sabatier principle since an optimum bond strength value matches with the highest HDS activity point [33–36]. As can be seen, the trends for Co-Mo-S and Ni-Mo-S are close to the highest predicted activity values when looking at the metal-sulphur bond strength or cohesive energy [34]. Therefore, the refineries widely accept NiMo and CoMo based bimetallic catalysts. This higher activity is caused by incorporating Co and Ni into MoS2, which lowers metal sulfur bond strength [35]. Promoter atoms of Ni and Co add 3d electrons to the Mo 4d bands and occupy the Mo-S anti-bonding sites (theoretical calculations showed that these sites are below the Fermi level) [33–35]. This creates a larger number of vacancies and increases surface reactions. Moreover, the high density of occupied states near the Fermi level implies back electrons bonding to the C-S anti-bonding orbitals and, hence, bond-cleavage, as has been elucidated more recently [30]. Lauritsen et al. [37] also performed scanning tunnelling microscopy (STM) and DFT to investigate the location and coordination of Co and Ni in MoS2-based catalysts. STM images of Co–Mo–S and Ni–Mo–S nanoclusters have been shown in Fig. 6, which clearly shows distinct morphology than bare catalyst e., g. Co-promoted MoS2 has a hexagonal truncated shape with the (10–10) Mo edge and (−1010) S edge (Fig. 9 a). DFT simulated STM images indicate that only 50 % of the sulphur-covered edge is consistent with the experimental STM images. The edge truncation effect for Ni-Mo-S is more complex and depends on cluster size. The more significant type A clusters adopt a hexagonal truncated shape (Fig. 9b), whereas smaller type-B clusters have more complex dodecagonal morphology (Fig. 9c). Ni–Mo–S type A clusters expose both an unpromoted (10–10) Mo edge and a new (−1010) Ni–Mo–S edge structure, in which Ni has fully substituted all edge Mo sites. It suggests that NiMoS/CoMoS site morphology also plays a vital role in the HDS activity. The active metals (NiMo, CoMo or NiW) are employed as unsupported (bulk) catalysts or supported catalysts. γ-Al2O3 is the most explored support for HDS reaction. But still, it is tough to fulfill the current environment legislations with these conventional NiMo, CoMo or NiW as bulk catalysts or supported on γ-Al2O3. Therefore, many efforts are being made to improve the catalytic activity of these conventional catalysts, and even some other cheap and accessible metals are also explored for HDS reaction like Niobium (Nb), Copper (Cu), Iron (Fe), Zinc (Zn) etc. In 2015, the Nb-doped NiW/Al2O3 catalyst showed slightly positive results for the HDS reaction [39] compared to the NiW/Al2O3 catalyst. In 2016, Palcheva et al., [40] investigated Nb metal as a modifier for SBA 15 and HMS support in NiMo-supported SBA15 or HMS catalysts and concluded that Nb-modified catalysts result in higher HDS activity than unmodified catalysts for both supports. They demonstrate this higher activity due to the higher Nb surface availability and better dispersion of active sites. They also reported that this activity is very sensitive to the pore structure of the support and the concentration of thioglycolic chelating agent. The scientific community was attracted to replacing MoS2 with NbS2, but in 2003, Wachs et al. clearly explained that formation of NbS2 from NbO is a thermodynamically limited phenomenon [41]. In 2018, Monsouri and Semagina [42] again addressed this issue and conducted many experiments by making alloys of Nb with different metal sulfides (V, Cd, Cu, Fe, Co, Mo, Cr, Zn, W). This investigation concluded that only Cu and Cd metals can promote this sulfidation process of Nb. Fig. 10 shows the change in thermodynamic parameters and various reactions in this process. As Cd is a very hazardous metal, Cu is used in this study for further experiments in which they have shown that Cu promoted NbS2 catalyst is more active than CoMo conventional catalysts. Iron (Fe) is a very inexpensive, environmentally friendly, and easily available metal. In 1980, Chianelli [43] reported in the “volcano curve” for unsupported sulfide catalysts (Fig. 8) that iron sulfide was not a good candidate for HDS catalyst although some literature studies show its promotion effect for Ni/Co MoS2/WS2 catalysts. These reports state that Fe could have a synergistic effect with Mo/W/Ni and result in better dispersion of active sites, but still, it was not comparable with CoMo or NiMo catalyst activity. Some research groups [43,44] reported the Zn-promoted FeS2 bimetallic catalysts named ferroan sphalerite (FeZnS) for HDS reaction. They explained in these studies that Zn incorporation in iron sulfide drastically increased its HDS activity (which is close to CoMoS2) due to change in electronic properties in which electron transfer from Zn to Fe. Further experimental and theoretical studies showed that incorporating Zn tuned the formation of sulphur vacancies, which is an essential factor for designing highly efficient Fe-based sulfide catalysts. Initially the most common support γ-Al2O3 was used for FeZnS catalyst but in 2020, Liu et al. [44] showed that CeO2 supported FeZnS catalyst gives higher activity than FeZnS/ γ-Al2O3 catalyst due to better dispersion of Fe species and decreasing Fe-O and Fe-S/FeZn-S bonds strength which increase the degree of sulfidation and active site of Fe/FeZn catalysts. The maximum conversion of 4,6-DMDBT is achieved when the ratio of Zn and Fe is 1:1. Vrinat research group published a series of articles on Ga modified HDS catalysts [45]. They explained that the addition of trivalent metal Gallium (Ga) in NiMo/CoMo/NiW supported on γ-Al2O3 catalysts increases HDS performance by changing the Ni/Co interaction with the support, As Ga has high affinity for γ-Al2O3 tetrahedral sites so it adsorbs at these tetrahedral sites and the ratio of Ni+2/Co+2 octahedral and tetrahedral sites increases that ultimately reduces the formation of NiAl2O4 and CoAl2O4 spinels. In 2017, Zhou et al. [46] investigated Ga as a promoter for NiMo supported on Y zeolites catalysts and concluded its positive effect for HDS process. Ga has lower electron negativity (1.59) as compared to Al (1.7), so Si-O(H)Al strong acidic sites are replaced by Si-O(H)Ga weak acidic sites that reduce the inhibition nature of Y zeolites for the formation of NiMoS active phase due to its strong acid strength. Except for sulfides, some phosphide catalysts were also explored for HDS reaction and Ni2P based catalysts showed best HDS performance as compared to other phosphides. Jang and lee [47] studied the promotion effect of Ga for Ni2P supported on SiO2 catalysts and explained that Ga cause the electron deficiency of Ni2P that leads to high HDS performance. It is shown here in Fig. 11 . Recently, Zhou et al. also studied effect of Ga incorporation in Ni2P/Al2O3 catalyst and showed higher HDS activity by Ga incorporations due to enhanced d electron density in Ni species boosting pre-hydrogenation [48]. Rh, Pd, Ru and Pt are the most explored noble metal catalysts for HDS reactions. The volcano curve plot (Fig. 8) clearly shows that RuS2, Rh2S3, PdS HDS activity results are very much close to NiMoS/CoMoS/NiWS catalyst combinations and noble metal catalysts can also operate at lower temperature and pressure conditions as compared to conventional refinery conditions for HDS process but high cost and sulfur poisoning limit the application of these catalysts in refineries. This high cost of noble metal catalysts can be compensated with low operating conditions cost but with increased HDS performance. Therefore, many research groups tried to improve HDS catalytic activity by investigating Ru, Rh, Pt, Pd based catalysts and some binary combinations of Ru, Rh and Pd, Pt etc. Various applications of noble metal catalysts, separately Rh and Pd metal-based catalysts have been critically reviewed by Ishihara et al. [49]., Kaluza et al. [50], and Fanglin et al. [51] respectively. Some of the recent work based on noble metal catalysts is explained here. Pd nanoparticles have attracted much more attention in last few years due to high resistance to sulfur poisoning and high HDS activity. But its prone nature to metal sintering have to be controlled for better performance. Monsouri and Semagina [52] addressed this issue and suggested that yttrium (Y) addition in Pd nanoparticles improve its thermal stability towards agglomeration. Alumina supported Pd-Y bimetallic catalyst did not increase the overall HDS rate but increased DDS selectivity around 15–20 % and reduced the cracking rate to almost half as compared to Pd based monometallic catalysts. It is well stabilized in literature that DDS route is followed by perpendicular adsorption (σ bond) and HYD by flat adsorption (п bond) so Pd-Y catalyst results high DDS selectivity because it favors perpendicular adsorption mechanism as shown in Fig. 12 . In 2018, Xu et al. [53] proposed a new approach to prepare highly dispersed Pd nanoparticles on the surface of HZSM-5 support by using two positive charge properties of decamethonium bromide. Decamethonium has Pd attached to its one end and HZSM-5 mesoporous support on its other end, which supports the high dispersion of Pd on HZSM-5 surface, as shown in Fig. 13 . This catalyst was reported to have higher HDS activity as compared to the impregnated Pd/HZSM-5 catalyst. 2.2 Multimetallic catalysts The volcano curve (see Fig. 8) for alumina-supported bimetallic catalysts shows that NiMoS, CoMoS, CoWS and NiWS catalyst combinations give the best synergistic effect. Further, in 2007, Thomazeau et al. [54] performed DFT calculations for different trimetallic combinations of these highly active bimetallic catalysts such as NiMoW, CoMoW etc. The volcano curve relationship for alumina-supported trimetallic catalyst is given in Fig. 14 . Metal sulfur bond energy was used as a descriptor for these DFT calculations. NiMo and NiW bimetallic catalyst combinations are positioned around the maximum activity point in the volcano curve, whereas CoMo and CoW combinations are located at the descending branch of the curve. Therefore, NiMoW trimetallic combination showed a better synergistic effect than the CoMoW for the HDS process. Many experimental studies, such as Amaya et al. [55], supported this conclusion and compared the HDS activity of NiMoW and CoMoW catalysts prepared by hydrothermal and co-precipitation methods using DBT as a model compound. This study explained that the NiMoW catalyst's higher activity is associated with its high hydrogenation capacity (see Fig. 15 ) as compared to the CoMoW catalyst. Many research groups modified these NiMoW trimetallic catalyst combinations for better HDS activity and concluded that activity is highly influenced by changing different supports [56], and Ni/Mo/W molar ratios [57]. Arturo et al. [58]., investigated NiMoW/CoMoW catalyst supported on TiO2 and ZrO2 modified SBA-15 for HDS reaction. They observed that NiMoW or CoMoW supported on SBA15-Zr catalysts were more active than NiMoW or CoMoW supported on SBA15 and SBA15-Ti catalysts. This high activity was attributed to the enhancement of hydrogenation capacity by introducing ZrO2, especially for NiMoW catalysts (best catalyst- NiMoW/Zr-SBA15). Further detailed discussion on the factors affecting the activity (i.e., support, methods, conditions of preparations and additives), is given in the following section. Hein et al., [59] studied the structure-activity relationships for NiMoW sulfide catalysts and explained that NiMoW catalyst consists of intralayer mixed MoxW1-x S2 slabs decorated by Ni at the perimeter of these Mo(W)S2 slabs. Phase segregation may also happen during sulfidation, forming mixed phases like Mo(W)S2, Ni-Mo(W)S2, Ni3S4 and Ni9S8. Traditionally, Nickel sulfides do not participate in the reaction as active sites (recently, few research works have focused on precisely removing these inactive segregated phases from the catalyst surface). Metal cations at the edges have a lower coordination number than the bulk. These metal cations are coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUS) which are considered to be the most suitable sites for sulfur removal. Fig. 16 represents the various sites on a NiMoW catalyst model, such as CUS sites, SH functional groups due to the hydrogen adsorption phenomenon, and edge brim sites. It shows the NiMoW catalyst slab from three edges (a) Mo edge (b) Mixed Mo-W edge (c) W edge, and the bond length of all possible bonds in all these three edges. Recently, noble metals like Ru and Pd promoted Ni(Co) Mo(W) catalysts and also emerged as new trimetallic catalysts [60]. It is one of the optimized activity enhancement strategies for HDS process, as a low amount of noble metal turns the reaction towards the HYD path that is mainly required for heavy sulfur molecules. A critical review on trimetallic catalysts was published in 2017 [61]. Apart from the promoters mentioned above, researchers have also tried using Au [62–64], Fe [65,66], and Rh [67,68] to enhance the activity of NiMo catalysts, but these are not being used commercially. Chen Li et al. [69] research group has published many articles based on multi metallic catalysts for HDS reaction. First, they reported a series of NixAlyMoW four metallic catalyst with layered structure and different mole ratios, prepared by NiAl-layered double hydroxide (NiAl-LDH) Co-precipitation method. One of these NiAlMoW catalysts combinations showed twice intrinsic HDS activity compared with commercial wet-impregnated CoNiMoW/Al2O3 catalyst for the HDS process. This activity improvement is explained by the high dispersion of active metal species at the surface and the edges of the layers. This great impact of layered structures on HDS activity given a motivation to use this phenomenon further for other metal combinations. The proposed scheme for this method is given here in Fig. 17 . In 2014, the same group reported NixZnyMoW four metallic [70] and again in 2015, NixZnyAlzMoW five metallic catalysts prepared by same NiZn-LDH method with different mole ratios. Recently, in 2024, Carmo et al., [71] studied tetrametallic unsupported CoMoMnAl and CoMoZnAl catalysts (prepared by LDH method) for HDS reaction and showed enhanced activity than industrial catalyst because of high active metal site dispersion generated due to synergistic metal composition. But still, multimetallic catalysts are a new area for the HDS process, and further studies are required in this field for better understanding. 3 Role of catalyst support To reach the goal of < 5 ppm sulphur levels in petroleum products, a variety of strategies have been employed in which variation of support is an important one [65–67]. Because catalyst support is crucial to the design of hydrotreating catalysts. The support can alter the structure, dispersion, electrical characteristics [72,73] and stacking degree of NiMoS/CoMoS active phases [10–15]. Support covers the active metal dispersion during severe operating conditions leading to the separation of metal particles and the prevention of their agglomeration. The activity of sulfided HDS catalysts often varies widely as a function of support composition, indicating that the sulfided active phase is extremely dependent on the nature and composition of the support. For maximum utilization of catalytically active metals, the supports generally used are porous, having high surface areas like silica, alumina, carbon and zeolites with surface areas in the range of 100–300 m2/g [12–14]. Specifically, HDS catalyst supports can be divided into two main categories: Oxide and non-oxide supports. The details are given in Fig. 18 , and some examples are shown in Table 2 : 3.1 Oxide supports ℽ-Al2O3 is widely employed as both an active catalyst and a support in the preparation of catalysts for HDS process due to its higher mechanical and thermal strength along with desired textural properties. As compared to other supports, such as silica, carbon, and titania, alumina is expected to exert stronger interactions with the active phases [79–81]. Strong metal-support interactions are advantageous in many ways, as they promote the formation of highly dispersed MoS2 structures that are stable during operation and can also facilitate re-dispersion during regeneration. However, alumina-supported catalysts are responsible for the formation of relatively less active Type-I sites due to this strong interaction with the active metal (forming strong Mo-O-Al bond) leading to lower reducibility or sulfidation degree. Therefore, ℽ-Al2O3 supported catalysts are not active enough for the complete removal of sulfur compounds. A lot of researchers have observed that the Mo(W) species has a weaker interaction with silica than with alumina. However, for silica supported catalysts, the Mo-support interaction is even weaker than the Co-Mo interaction, resulting to the development of weakly crystalline cobalt molybdate. Co promoted atoms are predominantly present as Co-Mo-S phases after sulfiding of silica-supported catalysts, although large amounts of Co9S8 are also produced [82,83]. Therefore, SiO2-modified alumina supports can enable the higher sulfidation of active species, resulting in the creation of Type II active sites (weaker metal-support interaction or higher reducibility) with enhanced HDS and HYD catalytic functions [84]. In 2006, Al Dalama et al. [83] (see Fig. 19 ) compared CoMo catalysts supported on ℽ-Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3 composite for HDS reaction performance and summarized that CoMo/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts showed higher activity than CoMo/ℽ-Al2O3 due to its weaker metal-support interaction and ability of forming lesser inactive sites. The addition of metal oxides such as MgO, Ga2O3, TiO2, and ZrO2 into ℽ-Al2O3 also modifies the active metal support interaction and, consequently, the HDS catalytic activity [85]. In 2007, Rana et al., [85] prepared all these mixed oxides supported catalysts and tested for HDS reaction (see Fig. 20 ). They observed that TiO2-Al2O3 composite support represent higher HDS activity for both NiMo and CoMo catalysts and the activity trend is given as TiO2-Al2O3 > ZrO2-Al2O3 > SiO2-Al2O3 = MgO-Al2O3 > Al2O3 for CoMo and TiO2-Al2O3 > ZrO2-Al2O3 > MgO-Al2O3 > SiO2-Al2O3 > Al2O3 for NiMo supported catalysts. The superior activity of TiO2-Al2O3 supported catalysts is attributed due to the partial sulfidation of TiO2 (Sulfided Ti+3 act as a promoter like Ni and Co). Vrinat research group published a lot of articles based on Ga2O3 modified alumina supports for HDS catalysts [86]. Because Ga possesses a great ability to replace tetrahedral Al sites in alumina and form GaAl2O4 phases in place of Ni/CoAl2O4 inactive phases, leading to the higher density of NiMoS/CoMoS active sites as the free Ni/Co interact more with MoS2. Even some group also reported the positive effects of Ga doping in zeolites for HDS catalysts due to higher acidic site formation and Co/Ni-MoS2 interactions [41,42,80]. Further, DFT simulations have also demonstrated each metal oxide structure and metal-support interactions as an HDS catalyst support. In 2018, Leon et al. [87] studied the support effects for NiW sulfided catalysts by calculating the heats of adsorption values for NiWS and WS2 interactions (Fig. 21 ) on various supports such as TiO2 (T), Al2O3 (A), SiO2 (S), ZrO2 (Z), TiO2-Al2O3 (AT) and TiO2-ZrO2 (ZT). They reported that catalysts supported on AT (maximum) and ZT composite supports showed the highest HDS activity due to optimum metal-support interaction, which enhances the Ni-W interaction, forming higher NiWS active phases. In 2023, botin et al., [88] studied Ni supported on ZnO2/SiO2/Al2O3 catalysts with different loading/support combinations and observed that 8-Ni/ZnO-SiO2 sample with high Ni loading (8 at Ni/nm2) showed the highest HDS/HYD selectivity for high thiophene conversion (96 %) due to high dispersion of Ni species on the support surface. Additionally, bare basic supports (without mixing with alumina) such as MgO have been tested for HDS reaction for two significant reasons. First, the acid–base interaction between acidic MoO3 and a basic support in the oxidic precursor of sulphide catalysts should promote a high and stable Mo species dispersion [88,89]. Second, the basic nature of the support should inhibit coking, which is comparatively intense with conventional Al2O3 catalysts [88–92]. But, one of the primary disadvantages of MgO-supported catalysts is that it is thermodynamically unstable compared to other supports used in HDS reactions [93]. The high surface area of MgO (100–300 m2/g) transforms into the low surface area (10–30 m2/g) by forming Mg(OH)2 after contacting with water. Even under ambient conditions, MgO appears to be converted to a mixture of MgCO3 and Mg(OH)2 during the aqueous impregnation of the metal salts of the active-phase precursors [94]. Due to the higher mechanical resistance and chemical stability, ZrO2 is also used as a support, among its other applications [95]. Pure zirconia is porous and has a low specific surface area (100 m2/g). Therefore, ZrO2 is incorporated into ordered siliceous materials to produce ZrO2 solids with a large surface area. Incorporating ZrO2 into SBA-15 improves the molybdenum dispersion [95,96]. Powder XRD analysis of CoMo/SBA-15 catalysts revealed an agglomerated CoMoO4 phase, which was prevented by modifying SBA-15 support with ZrO2. This is due to a greater interaction between Co and the ZrO2-containing support. Identical findings were also discovered for NiMo catalysts. These catalysts supported on ZrO2-modified SBA-15 exhibited high activity for HDS reaction of thiophene, DBT, and 4,6- DMDBT [96–99]. It was discovered that the catalytic activity was greater compared to conventional Al2O3 support [99]. 3.2 Non oxide supports As a neutral support, carbon [100] has been investigated as a viable commercial support for hydrotreating catalysts. Various carbonaceous materials such as activated carbon, carbon black [101], carbon nanotubes (single and multiwalled) [102,103], carbon nano fibres [85], graphene [104] and graphene oxide [105] etc., were explored as catalytic support for HDS catalysts. These carbon-supported CoMoS/NiMoS structures [106,107] are less strongly attached to the support than alumina-supported CoMoS/NiMoS structures. Further, these catalysts also possess higher surface area, wide pore distribution, surface functional groups and lesser coking ability. In addition, the absence of oxygen connections to the active phases in carbon-supported catalysts suggests that the characteristics of active phases on carbon may differ from those on alumina. The active sites discovered in carbon-supported catalysts sulfided at lower temperatures having similar properties to Type-II sites, based on the fact that support interactions are less critical for Type-II sites than Type-I sites. The heavier sulphur compounds (i.e., 4,6-DMDBT) can be converted into a more reactive molecule via demethylation or isomerization route [108,109], These acid-catalyzed reactions were conducted on bifunctional catalysts, such as alumina-supported sulphide catalysts along with an acidic component [110,111] such as zeolite (i.e., MCM-41), zeolite and SBA-15 or SBA-16 composite [112] supported catalysts [113–115]. In addition, natural and pillared clays, which offer large specific surface areas, thermal and mechanical resistance, and acidic characteristics, also explored as catalytic supports for HDS catalysts [116,117]. The 4,6-DMDBT conversion was greatly boosted using these kinds of catalysts. However, zeolite incorporation in alumina can induce acidity on the catalyst surface and in case of highly acidic surfaces, basic nitrogen compounds present in petroleum feed may strongly adsorb on these acid sites leading to the cracking of hydrocarbons into light hydrocarbons. This cracking will accelerate coke production, resulting in the deactivation of the catalyst over the long term [118–121]. Therefore, composition of zeolite and alumina in support mixtures plays the major role in the catalyst design because optimum acidity is actually desired for higher HDS activity and stability. In addition to providing acidity, zeolites also give a well-defined and organized pore structure at the molecular level. High dispersions of intra-zeolite clusters may provide HDS catalysts more MoS2 edge sites [120,121]. However, the microporous structure of zeolite increases the mass transport resistance for bigger molecules. Therefore, most of the studies have explored specially prepared meso‑microporous zeolites or composites of zeolites with silica components (SBA 15 or SBA 16 having large pore size 16–17 nm) as a support for HDS catalysts. In 2018, Zhou et al. [122], reported NiMo supported on meso‑microporous Y zeolites (NiMo/MY-x, x is the diameter of mesopores) catalysts and tested it for HDS reaction of 4, 6 DMDBT reactant molecule. They claimed in this study that introducing the mesopores in the prepared zeolite support, has enhanced the Al+3 polarization effect, leading to reduced metal-support interaction or higher Ni and Mo sulfidation degree along with optimum acidity and negligible mass transport resistance. Therefore, NiMo/MY-6 and NiMo/MY-8 catalysts showed higher catalytic activity than other prepared catalysts at all reaction temperatures (Fig. 22 ). In 2020, Shi et al., [123] reported a self-assembly method to prepare NiMo supported on SBA16 incorporated ZSM-5 support (NiMo/ZS-x, x is the zeolite crystallization temperature) and claimed that NiMo/ZS-160 catalysts showed highest desulfurization activity (Fig. 23 ) due to the higher Bronsted acid sites, negligible diffusion limitation, higher surface area and higher edge dispersion. The activation stage that changes the catalysts from the oxide state to the active sulfided state is crucial to the performance of the HDS catalyst, and the support may play a key role in this sulfidation process. The support (by altering metal-support interaction) can accelerate or retard the sulfidation process and affect not only the final dispersion state but also the final chemical state [85,104]. The degree of sulfidation appears to be the major distinction between Type-I and Type–II Co(Ni)-Mo-S phases, as opposed to other morphological properties, such as the degree of stacking, for which multiple investigations have shown contradicting results. On the basis of their support, considerable changes in the activity and selectivity of HDS catalysts were found [104,105]. 3.3 Effect of additives on the catalyst support 3.3.1 Effect of alkali /rare earth metals Potassium, sodium, and other basic metals decreased the HDS activity of the catalyst upon addition due to the gradual destruction of the polymolybdate phase and the subsequent formation of K2MoO4 and Na2MoO4. However, despite its basic nature, Zn demonstrated an increase in catalytic activity because it increases the ratio of octahedral Mo to tetrahedral Mo and the reducibility of the catalyst. This is due to the fact that Zn occupies the tetrahedral sites in alumina, reducing the concentration of tetrahedral Mo. In 2023, Liu et al., [124] studied La incorporation in NiMo/Al2O3 catalysts for 4,6 DMDBT desulfurization reaction, which showed the higher activity by weakening Mo-O-Al bond in catalysts and producing enhanced Type II sites. Even though Ca modification induces some of the Mo atoms to switch from octahedral coordination to tetrahedral coordination and decreases the reducibility (Mo4+/Mo6+) of the catalyst. However, many research reports indicate that a CaO loading of 10 wt % on alumina maintains its mesoporous nature and increases the relative sulfidability (S/Mo4+) or activity of the catalyst as higher metal loading promotes the octahedral Mo coordination. 3.3.2 Effect of non-alkali metals 3.3.2.5 Effect of boron The incorporation of a small amount of B2O3 (up to 3 wt. %) as an additive produces a support with slightly improved textural properties and creates interconnected pores as well as irregular surfaces which results in a slightly higher surface area at low boron content. Moreover, as the boron content increases, the surface area decreases due to the blocking of Al2O3 pores by B2O3 [125]. The addition of B results in the formation of a boron monolayer in the form of B2O3 with B occupying tetrahedral sites, thereby increasing the fraction of octahedral sites available to Ni and Mo [125]. The addition of B2O3 in Al2O3 resulted in an increase in the acidic property of the catalyst and even the overall acidity of the catalyst can be manipulated by controlling the boria level. The acidity of B2O3-Al2O3 is attributed to the formation of borates on the alumina surface [125]. Therefore, B2O3-modified alumina as a support for an HDS catalyst is more active than boron-free catalysts. 3.3.2.6 Effect of phosphorus Incorporation of phosphorus improves the dispersion of calcined Mo oxides phase and increases the sulfidability/reducibility of Mo attached to the alumina surface through Mo-O-Al bond, creating P-O-Al bonds [126]. At small concentration, phosphorus removes the strong alumina surface sites, so Ni2+ interacts less with the support (formation of AlPO4- type surface phase in place of NiAl2O4) leading to the formation of more efficient NiMoS active phases (more Ni atoms along the MoS2 crystallite edges) [126,127]. Additionally, incorporation of P also showed enhanced acidity by forming phosphate anions. However, many reports suggest that at greater P loadings, bulk crystalline MoO3 forms at catalyst surface, reducing dispersion or activity for HDS process [128]. Further, P incorporation by post-metal impregnation, can create irreducible polymolybdate species, lowering HDS activity. Most investigations over a variety of P concentrations reveal optimum action around 1 % [128]. Other research claim phosphorus has a negligible [129] or negative effect on HDS activity. In this investigation, very high Ni loadings led P to segregate Ni atoms. 3.3.2.7 Effect of fluorine Fluorine interacts strongly with acid sites like Al3+ cations on alumina surface due to its high electronegativity and small atomic radius resulting lower metal-support interaction. So that molybdate and tungstate anions are no longer strongly attached to the support and are mostly polyanions that can be readily sulfided to MoS2 and WS2 crystallites. In addition, weaker Mo and W interactions with the support resulted to increased stacking of MoS2 and WS2 crystallites suggesting more active type II Ni–Mo–S and Co–Mo–S phases formation [130]. F enhances the acidity of the catalyst, which permits methyl groups in 4-MDBT and 4,6-DMDBT to migrate, removing steric hindrance to the C-S-C link in the reactant and increasing HDS activity [131]. However, HDS reaction rate increases up to 3–4 wt % F, then decreases due to lower surface area because of blocking of alumina pores by F. Even, various HDS catalysts have different optimal F content values such as HDS activity rose up to 3 wt % F in NiMo/Al2O3, but dropped above 2 wt % F in CoMo/Al2O3 and for NiW/Al2O3, thiophene HDS activity was highest at 4 % F loading. Therefore, the preparation methods and conditions are also very important feature for these types of catalysts. 4 Unsupported catalyst In recent years, after the development of Nebula [130,132] and Star [133,134] unsupported catalysts (the highest active (100 %) hydrotreating catalyst) for HDS reaction, the focus of researchers has shifted to the preparation of novel unsupported catalysts. Various groups have studied different methods of preparation and the activities of the so-obtained catalysts for HDS reaction. The behaviour of these catalysts in terms of activity and selectivity is heavily dependent on the preparation technique, the use of catalyst precursors and activation techniques. Even then, some trends have been observed when comparing these catalysts to the corresponding supported ones, such as unsupported catalysts showing a higher number of active sites, reducibility, and stacking [135,136]. As can be reasonably expected, the HYD selectivity of these catalysts increased but still, these catalysts are limited due to agglomeration, higher amount of inactive segregated phases (e.g., NixSy), low dispersion of active sites and higher hydrogen consumption. These catalysts are mainly prepared by hydrothermal synthesis where ammonium-thiomolybdates ATM or ammonium-tungstates (ATT) are heated to give Mo(W) sulfide species. Two different approaches have been used for these catalysts. First is insitu activation, in which the ATM or ATT slats are thermally decomposed in liquid phase inside the reactor during the HDS reaction and second is ex-situ activation where the precursor is treated with H2/H2S gas along with heating to convert it to MoS2/WS2 phases. Promoter salt solutions are added to these precursors to give the bimetallic and the trimetallic catalysts. The effect of promoters on the catalyst dispersion and morphology is similar to those observed in the supported catalysts (improved selectivity towards the DDS pathway) [136]. The activation or sulfidation method can affect the final characteristics and performance of the synthesized unsupported catalysts [137]. In the initial studies, properties of in situ and ex-situ activated MoS2 and WS2 catalysts synthesized using ATM and ATT were compared and summarized that in-situ activated catalysts showed a higher surface area or porosity and HDS activity than exsitu activated catalysts [137]. This was attributed to a better stability of the catalyst due to a weaker reduction conducted in the presence of carbon compounds rather than H2 along with a more efficient dissipation of heat during the decomposition. Alkyl substitutes of the ammonium compounds have also been reported as precursors to obtain unsupported catalysts. To explain the role of carbon species for these catalysts, Alvarez et al. [138] studied NiMo unsupported catalysts using (R4N)2MoS4 (R = H, methyl, propyl and butyl) precursors. They summarized that carbon species have changed the morphological and textural properties of the catalysts (Fig. 24 ). Adding the alkyl groups from C1 to C4, the catalysts isotherm changed to type IV with higher surface area (especially more in case of in-situ activation), while the activity is a little higher for C4 precursor catalysts than non-alkyl precursor catalysts and C1 C3 precursor catalysts showed lesser activity than non-alkyl precursor catalysts. Therefore, the role of carbon containing precursors is very complex because it showed two opposite effects. The negative effect is that excess carbon can block the MoS2 active sites and the positive point is that it can form surface-carbide-like structures promoting the HDS activity. Further, Alonso et al. [139], observed a cheese-like morphology with a mesoporous structure (named as amorphous mesoporous sulfides, Fig. 25 ) for MoS2 unsupported catalysts prepared by thermal decomposition of long chain precursors ((R4N)2MoS4 (R = propyl, butyl, pentyl, hexyl, heptyl and octyl) [139]. This was due to the pressure developed by the vaporization of organic constituents during the decomposition of precursor salts. They showed that this mesoporous structure totally changed the structure of the catalyst and surface increased from 60 to 329 m2/g. But still the HDS activity is almost similar to non-alkyl precursor catalysts as large amount carbon is deposited on the catalyst surface. Apart from this overall method, other techniques, such as a combination of precursor salts with elemental sulfur [135] and sonochemical synthesis, have also been tried to obtain desirable unsupported catalysts. In addition, supported catalysts were also modified to unsupported ones by the support leaching method using acids such as HF, HCl etc., [13]. In these studies, the catalyst morphology and properties are changed, like higher surface area better dispersion than bare MoS2 catalysts, which slightly changed the activity. Although several studies have been conducted on unsupported catalysts prepared by thermal synthesis from ATM (ATT)s and tetra-alkyl ATM(ATT)s, there are still some unanswered questions, such as the direct connection of activity and activation methods, the complex behaviour of carbon-containing precursors for NiMo and CoMo catalysts. Therefore, insight into the quantitative connection between increased surface area and the activity of these catalysts and the origin of the different observed selectivity trends needs to be obtained. 5 Effect of sulfidation conditions The HDS catalyst is usually oxidised after calcination and needs to be pre-sulfided before the HDS reaction. In the sulfiding process, the Ni/Co-promoted MoO3/WO3 phase is converted to Ni/Co decorated MoS2/WS2 (NiMoS/CoMoS) phase, forming intermediate oxy-sulfides. It is believed that HDS activity is mainly based on the formation of NiMoS/CoMoS phases, which ultimately leads to the creation of sulfur vacancies [7,8]. Based on the conditions, MoO3 may also reduce to MoO2 before getting sulfided (as the reduction and sulfidation process happen simultaneously), and MoO2 is very difficult to sulfide, leading to partial sulfiding of the catalyst. Therefore, the sulfiding procedure (drying, startup of sulfiding feed, pressurizing the reactor at the desired value) and parameters such as the temperature, partial pressure of hydrogen, nature of sulfiding agent, ramp rate, concentration of sulfiding agent etc., are very sensitive to the degree of sulfidation of the catalyst [9–13]. 5.1 Different forms of sulfidations The prepared catalyst is in the oxide form and has to be sulfided to form the active phase. The sulfiding can be done either outside the reactor (ex situ sulfiding) or inside (in situ sulfiding). 5.1.1 Ex situ sulfiding This method involves "wetting" supported oxides ex situ with a high-molecular-weight alkyl polysulfide. Alkyl polysulfide's contact with the surface of an industrial Co (Ni)-Mo catalyst is sufficient to partially decrease both sulfur and molybdenum species [140]. Pre-sulfided catalyst is activated in situ, under hydrogen pressure, in the presence of hydrocarbon liquid phase, following thermal treatment. Exsitu sulfiding leads to a greater dispersion of the sulfided active phase, and it is also a quicker and less complex method for activating the catalyst. In recent years, ex situ sulfided catalysts have been employed commercially and have demonstrated superior activity and stability compared to catalysts sulfided by spiking agents or feed sulphur. But still, this sulfiding process has several problems, including high cost, inconsistent activation times, and safety during transportation and storage of highly active and hazardous chemicals, etc. Therefore, most refiners and researchers use in situ sulfiding to activate oxidic catalysts [141]. 5.1.2 In situ sulfiding In-situ sulfiding, the catalyst is activated inside the reactor using a gas phase sulfiding agent e.g., H2S and H2 gas mixture or liquid sulfur compounds (spiking agent) e.g., dimethyl disulfide (DMDS). Various sulfiding situations are explained in the following section: Sulfidation by a gaseous mixture of hydrogen sulfide and hydrogen: This is mostly used in laboratory work because of its ease of handling and analysis. In general, the method consists of drying the catalyst at high temperature by a constant flow of inert gas such as helium, argon or nitrogen. Then, the sulfiding gas mixture conditions are maintained as per desired protocol. Sulfidation by a non-spiked feed of hydrocarbon: In this method the sulfiding is done by utilizing the sulfur compounds present in the feed. Under a flow of hydrogen, H2S is produced and that sulfides the catalyst. Generally, when feed contains large amount of sulfur then it can also be used in sulfiding. Sulfiding by a spiked feed: In this case, spiking agent is added to the feed and the sulfur from this agent is mainly responsible for the sulfidation. Spiking agents are sulfur-containing organic compounds that release H2S at a lower temperature than petroleum feedstock. Carbon disulfide (CS2), dimethyl sulfide (DMS), DMDS, butanethiol, ditertio-nonylpentasulfide, ethyl mercaptan, dimethyl sulfoxide, and n‑butyl mercaptan etc., are used for the sulfidation process of the HDS catalysts. The required amount of spiking agent depends on the amount of catalyst to be sulfided such as in case of NiMo catalyst, MoO3 and NiO amount can be calculated, along with the amount of sulfur needed to form MoS2 and Ni3S8. Generally, some extra sulfiding agent is taken to compensate any kind of disturbance during the reaction. In commercial reactors, the reactor effluent during sulfiding is first sent to a separator for separating the gas and liquid, and the gas, which contains mostly H2S and hydrogen (during sulfiding) is recycled. Hence, all the H2S evolved during decomposition of DMDS is used in sulfiding the feed [142–145]. 6 Effect of preparation methods The catalyst is the major part for the HDS process of petroleum feedstocks. Supported catalysts are frequently utilized in the industry because they provide great dispersion, attrition resistance, hardness, compressive strength, heat stability and support stability under reaction and regeneration circumstances. Alumina is the most common hydroprocessing catalyst support and MoS2 particles boosted with Ni or Co form the HDS active phase (NiMoS/CoMoS). However, NiSx/Co9S8 and Co(Ni)Al2O4 phases can also be formed but these do not catalyze the HDS reaction [146] (Fig. 26 ). There are different methods for the synthesis of HDS catalysts out of which impregnation is the most commonly used method. However, major limitations in the synthesis of conventional catalyst using impregnation method are the lack of control over the size of the crystallites formed and the non-uniformity of active metal distribution on the support. Except impregnation there are few other methods that also had been tried for the synthesis of HDS catalyst which includes: organic matrix combustion (OMXC) [147–148], hydrothermal synthesis [149] and sonochemical synthesis [150] etc. In impregnation method a precursor solution of the active metal(s) is brought in contact with the support and after the precursor salt is deposited on the support, it is subjected to calcination to bring the active metal particles to their native oxide form. Normally calcination temperatures for HDS catalyst are kept around 400–600 °C [18]. This temperature is high enough to ensure full decomposition of precursor salt and at the same time is sufficiently low enough to prevent the solid-solid reaction between metal oxide and the support. At high enough calcination temperatures, diffusion of promoter atoms can take place on the alumina subsurface. This can lead to the formation of catalytically inactive cobalt/nickel aluminate phases [146]. It has been reported that when calcination temperature is ∼ 700 °C, formation of Al2(MoO4)3 may also take place. This catalyst is then transformed into the required active metal sulfide form before starting the HDS reaction. In case of higher catalyst loading is needed, successive impregnations (and heat treatments) may be necessary, and for bimetallic or trimetallic catalysts, the sequential impregnation method has also been explored. The sequence of various metal impregnation plays a significant role in these catalysts because the interaction among metals determines the formation of the final active phase of the catalyst. Recently, Liu et al., [151] reported the development of one-dimensional 3D printing method to prepare desulfurization catalysts. The NiMo/Al2O3 monolithic catalyst prepared by the 3D printing strategy (3D-NiMo/Al2O3) exhibits hierarchical structure due to the combustion of hydroxymethyl cellulose serving as adhesive, which endows the weaker metal-support-interaction between Mo oxides and Al2O3, remarkably promoting sulfidation of both Mo and Ni species and the formation of “Type II” NiMoS active phase. Also, Zhu et al., [152] studied 3D printing method for NiMo/ Al2O3−MMT catalysts and explained that the synthetic effect between the MMT binder and the Al2O3 substrate, which effectively weakens the interaction between the Mo species and the Lewis acids on the original Al2O3 surface, thereby significantly increasing the content of reducible Mo species and considerably facilitating the formation of more highly active NiMoS phase (Type II) with optimal average stacking layers and thereafter remarkably enhancing the ultradeep HDS activity of the 3D-NiMo/Al2O3−MMT monolithic catalyst. Another report introduced a preparation technique for NiMo/Ti-SBA-15 catalyst, and this approach is actually a combination of sol-gel and hydrothermal synthesis processes. They used the conventional method for SBA-15 preparation but added the Ti precursor following the NiMo precursor before the hydrolysis of TEOS. A higher HDS activity was recorded for this single-pot synthesized catalyst than for the impregnated NiMo catalyst due to the incorporation of active phase inside the support's mesoporous framework, resulting in highly dispersed active sites along with its good textural properties and surface acidity. In 2018, Wang et al., [153] developed a self-assembly method for the preparation of ZSM-5/SBA-16 (ZS) support series (Fig. 27 ) having various SiO2/Al2O3 ratio and demonstrated that the NiMo supported on ZSM-5/SBA-16 (specially NiMo/ZS-3, SiO2/Al2O3 = 100) catalysts showed a uniformly dispersed morphology, higher acid sites, moderate metal-support interaction and well-ordered pore structure which ultimately exhibited higher increment in HDS catalytic activity compared to the conventional NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst. Recently, a few reports have addressed the colloidal synthesis techniques used to prepare various HDS catalysts. Sivakumar research group [154–156] published articles based on the alumina-supported NiMo, CoMo, NiW and NiMoW nanocatalysts prepared by the colloidal synthesis method for HDS reaction. In this method, precursors form a complex with Oleylamine solvent in the presence of two other surfactants, and this complex is decomposed at 230 °C temperature, leading to the formation of metal oxide nanoclusters during calcination of the prepared catalyst sample (Fig. 28 ). This catalyst showed higher activity than the conventional wet-impregnated NiMo catalyst due to the optimum metal-support interaction, stacking degree, small particle size 3–4 nm and uniform dispersion of active metal phases. Using all these above-mentioned preparation techniques, the main goal is to prepare highly active HDS catalyst having more and more type 2 sites (NiMoS/CoMoS). In the pre-sulfidation calcined state of a HDS catalyst, the promoter atoms that occupy octahedral positions instead of tetrahedral positions are seen to form the mixed sulfide active and inactive phases [18,49]. Whereas, the metals species that occupy octahedral position have higher sulfidability and hence leads to formation of Type II structures [18]. Hence, calcination temperature, many additives and other external methods have been used to increase the chances of promoter atoms occupying octahedral sites. In addition, within these various catalyst preparation methods, there are several factors that results in better metal dispersion and hence, improved catalyst activity. Some of these different approaches are discussed here in detail. 6.1 Effect of chelating agents A chelating agent is a compound containing two or more potential electron-pair donor atoms that can act as ligands and bind to a metal ion. It can be claimed that the creation of a metal chelate is a Lewis acid–base reaction. The most explored chelating agents for HDS supported catalysts are citric acid (CA), nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA), and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) [156,157]. The structure of chelating agents is an essential component which plays a major for the synthesis of new catalytic materials. Further, it is a well-known fact that when the promoter is positioned at the edges and corners of the MoS2 crystallites, formation of an efficient active phase is accomplished. As mentioned above, Ni/Co can also react with the support to generate Ni/CoAl2O4 inactive phases or, upon sulfation at low temperatures (180 °C), inactive NiSx/Co9S8 phases. When a chelating agent is introduced to impregnating solutions containing Ni (or Co) and Mo precursors, the development of a Co(Ni)-chelating ligand complex delays the sulfidation of the Co or Ni promoter at temperatures over 200 °C [158]. This results in an increase in the decorating of promoter Ni(Co) species on the perimeter of MoS2 slabs and a decrease in the creation of inactive bulk Co or Ni sulfides [159]. Citric acid is used as a chelating agent due to its low cost, non-toxic products, ease of manipulation, and synthesis of stable coordination compounds in aqueous solution [159,160]. Experiments revealed that the insertion of CA not only reduce the formation of inactive sites (NiSx/Co9S8) but also promote the dispersion of Ni/Co and Mo species, resulting in a larger amount of Ni-Mo-S/Co–Mo–S phase after sulfidation [160]. The activity of NiMo catalysts impregnated with citric acid was three times that of NiMo catalysts without citric acid. Experimentally, a CA: Mo molar ratio of 1 was determined to be the optimal quantity of citric acid in the impregnation solution for achieving the greatest catalytic activity. With continued citric acid addition, excess citric acid combines with support surface groups, reducing the quantity of citric acid accessible for interaction with Mo species in the solution. This results in the aggregation of Mo species during calcination, hence decreasing catalytic activity. NTA and EDTA are both often utilized as chelating agents. When NTA or EDTA was added to the impregnation solution [157–160], the HDS activity of CoMo and NiMo improved significantly because this agent inhibits Mo-support interaction, resulting in the development of exceptionally HDS-active CoMoS/NiMoS (Type-II) sites with excellent selectivity. In addition, as with CA, it was shown that these chelating compounds alter the sulfiding process of Ni by making Ni-EDTA/NTA complex, which results in a greater dispersion of the promoter on the borders of the MoS2 slabs [160], and consequently a larger HDS activity. 6.2 Effect of pH In the process of catalyst preparation, the support is exposed to various conditions, which may result in deterioration of the structure and properties of the support. But for HDS catalysts, it is preferable that the support retains its textural and structural integrity along with higher dispersion of active phase and moderate metal-support interaction in order to achieve a high level of catalytic activity. The dispersion and Mo-support interactions for these catalysts mainly depend on the pH of the impregnation solution and the isoelectric point of the support (IEP such as for alumina-pH-8 and for SBA15-pH 2.5). At lower pH values than IEP pH, the support will be positively charged which will give higher molybdates adsorption while at higher pH than IEP pH, the support will be negatively charged and so whether Ni ions will contact with support or Ni and Mo ions interact with each other (see Fig. 29 ). In addition, Rayo et al. [161] also examined the stability of SBA-15 in the acidic and basic conditions typically used to manufacture hydrotreating catalysts. Due to the pH of the impregnating solutions, significant changes in the structure and texture of SBA-15 were noticed during catalyst production. Under basic conditions, employing NH4OH solution, the hexagonal pore arrangement was destroyed, and the pore walls were significantly dissolved. This resulted in a significant reduction in surface area and pore volume [161]. The structural integrity of the SBA-15 was shown to be maintained for catalysts synthesized in acidic conditions [162]. Therefore, the HDS activity of thiophene was shown to be greater for catalysts produced under acidic conditions [140]. Further, for Mo/Al2O3 catalysts manufactured using the pore volume impregnation method, a change in pH from 11 to 4 had no significant impact on the architecture of the final catalysts, but an improvement in Mo dispersion and weak metal-support interaction were noted by decreasing pH [163]. The same kind of results were also observed for mixed-oxides supported systems such as the DBT HDS activity of the catalyst prepared at pH 4 was the higher than the catalyst prepared at pH 9. This increased activity was attributable to a greater concentration of HDS-active NiWS phase produced in the catalyst synthesized at pH = 4 than at pH = 9 [164]. Additionally, these pH-sensitive situations can be treated by using chelating agents like NiMoCA/SBA-15 catalysts produced by simultaneously impregnating Ni and Mo species with CA in acidic or basic solutions (pH = 1 or 9, respectively). The addition of citric acid to the impregnation solution stabilizes the catalyst system across a broad pH range and prevents Ni(OH)2 precipitation at basic pH [165]. Because Ni will be present as Ni+2 in acidic condition and form Nicit2 4- complex (Ni octahedrally coordinated with CA) in basic condition, both lead to NiMoS phases forming after sulfidation. 7 Effect of reaction conditions HDS reaction occurs at very high temperature (275–400℃) and pressure (10–150 atm) ranges which mainly depends on various composition reactant oil feed. Some of the recent studies based on effect of operating condition for HDS catalysts are tabulated here in Table 3 . Mostly similar trends were observed for different reaction variables and that is why effect of reaction conditions is considered as well optimized field for HDS reactions. Temperature increment may improve the HDS performance but catalyst sintering and other handling problems limit these values up to the above-mentioned range. In the same way optimum reactant flow rate or space velocity (LHSV- liquid hourly space velocity) is also a very important feature for HDS reaction because as space velocity of feed increases, residence time of reactant decreases that, ultimately reducing the reaction performance and lower values of space velocity may produce hydraulic issues [19]. Hydrogen plays multiple roles in HDS reaction process like the creation of sulfur vacancy, cleavage of C-S bond and ring hydrogenation reaction, therefore, suitable hydrogen pressure is the primary requirement for HDS process. It has been clearly explained earlier that low level of sulfur is difficult to achieve, because of the presence of heavy refractory sulfur compounds in the petroleum feedstock and these compounds mostly prefer the hydrogenation reaction pathways (high H2 consumption) (HYD) than DDS to avoid steric hindrance. So, high H2 pressure required for ultra-low sulfur petroleum compounds. But due to the limitation of high cost and handling problems, pressure values cannot be used beyond a certain limit [145]. Gas/oil ratio is the ratio of total gas fed in to the reactor to the amount of reactant. It is a very important parameter to control the reaction performance [174]. As gas/oil ratio increased, HDS activity will increase but after a certain point, the activity shows a plateau. If its value is too low, it will result in rapid catalyst deactivation and mass transfer limitation also retard the reaction. Further, hydrogen disulfide (H2S) produced during the process inhibits HDS reaction as H2S competes the adsorption of the organosulfur compound for the same catalytic active sites. So H2S is generally removed from the reactor in the amine unit of hydrotreating process [175]. 8 Summary This review paper critically analyzed and discussed following points for hydrodesulfurization process and catalysts: 1) All possible aspects (catalyst morphology, size, surface area, acids sites and metal-support interactions) to consider before designing a HDS catalyst 2) Selection of metals and their importance in catalysts 3) Selection of support and their effect on the activity of the reaction 4) Various parameters to possess a highly active/stable catalyst: catalyst preparation method and catalyst sulfidation before reaction 5) Reaction conditions. The readers can have the complete summary of the experimental as well as theoretical literature available based on above mentioned parameters for HDS reaction. According to literature, HDS reaction performance is controlled by the active sites (NiMoS/CoMoS) formation which provide the sulfur vacancies for the completion of the reaction and formation of these active sites depend on the catalyst structure and properties. Based on this analysis, future HDS catalyst design should be focused on the presence of higher active sites (NiMoS/CoMoS) with optimum stacking degree and hydrogenation sites, which can be demonstrated by preparing catalysts with controlled Mo-O-support interaction or higher Ni-Mo interaction (type II sites/high sulfidation degree) along with high metal species dispersion. Therefore, designing of an ideal HDS catalyst is the key to achieve breakthrough HDS activity. To explain it in detail, Table 4 also summarize the various explored HDS catalysts and their comparison based on their performances. This review paper summarized the available studies focused on the desired properties, morphology and structure of catalysts for superior HDS performance [183–185]. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is a catalytic process, which is used in petroleum refineries to reach sulfur levels <5 ppm of energy fuels due to its higher rate and activity for desulfurization. HDS reaction performance is mainly controlled by the sulfided phase of catalysts e.g., NiMoS/CoMoS sites for NiMo/CoMo based catalysts, and the formation of these sites depends on the catalyst design properties such as active metal dispersion, metal-support interaction, physiochemical properties like surface area/porosity and structure/morphology of catalysts based on their preparation methods/sulfidation conditions. In addition, operating conditions of reaction also govern the performance of the HDS process. A significant number of theoretical as well as experimental studies is available in literature, exploring various catalysts/technologies for HDS reaction. This review paper summarizes all these available strategies in detail and specially focuses on the effect of all mentioned parameters on HDS catalyst activity. Further, this work also discusses the required design charactertics for an ideal HDS catalyst. The prime concern of this review study is focused on highlighting and filling the gap between experimental and theoretical explanations for HDS catalysts, which is very important to analyze the HDS process performance.
